comms: This kind of marking co-exists with the [SUBJ; GEN] encoding, hence the verb is classified as ACT_UND.
comms_internal: The [SUBJ; GEN] pattern is observed here: https://news.abs-cbn.com/life/04/09/23/in-qc-this-dumpsite-turned-urban-farm-springs-happiness-hope-to-pwds. Although this is ultimately classified as ACT_UND, this strcture co-exists with the LV construction: “Na-i~impluwensya-han ng edad ang memorya” [POT-IPFV~influence-LV GEN age SUBJ memory] “Age influences memory” .

I used a transformation suggested by Serkey Klimenko. In fact, according to Rowena, both 1a “Naroroon si Pedro sa dakong kinasalubungan ko ng taong iyon” and 1b. “Naroroon si Pedro sa dakong kinasalubungan ko sa taong iyon” are okay. Although these two sentences are difficult to parse, it is okay if one interprets the -an as a locative, making the "dako" the ang-phrase or subject. Alternative is a construction with a reciprocal verb (Nag-ka-salubong) where X and Y are encoded as conjoined NPs.

sentence: t<in>a~tawag na compass ang gamit na ito
glosses_en: <PV>IPFV~call LIN compass SUBJ tool LIN PRX.SUBJ
comms_internal: Same verb as 31, different pattern. ‘This tool’ has the status I identify as UND (PV & SBJ). However, ‘compass’ is not an ACT (‘Indeed, one can add an agent with a ng- phrase (tinatawag na compass ang gamit na ito ng mga scientists “scientists call this tool a compass”), so the “na compass” does seem to be something else»). The label LIN is somewhat arbitrary though, but it signals some special relation to the predicate.

comms: The valency label is partially arbitrary, since this verb does not fit the usual scheme: the encoding of arguments is not affected by the contrast between voice markers on the verb.
comms_internal: Judging from this example, the status of X-argument, ‘Pedro’, is UND. But treating Y as ACT is problematic for both semantic reasons (no control) and the encoding in the AV construction: cf. “Nag-kulang ng piso si Pedro“ [AV.PFV-short GEN one_peso PERS.SUBJ PN] ‘Pedro is one peso short.’Taken in isolation, this structure would have analyzed as ACT_UND. Sergey Klimenko: "Some verb roots can form verbs of different voices but having the same meaning. E.g, s<um>ipag <AV>persevere vs sipag-in persevere-NAV. I don't think they form a single voice paradigm (since the participant marking stays the same). The use of the NAV verb probably indicates reduced control over the situation, but to my knowledge there is not hard evidence of this. I would say that piso here is UND as it can be marked with ng/sa. Also, there is a corresponding voice form. If it was nagkulang, Si Pedro would definitely be ACT. However with kinulang, it's probably what I label as experiencer - a participant that's used only in the subject position and the voice marking is not that of AV."

comms: Non-verbal predicate. The GEN marker on the Y-argument signals indefiniteness (otherwise SUBJ is required). Co-exists with the construction in 129. The pattern is exceptional and cannot be fitted into the classification based on voice contrasts.
sentence: gusto ni Pedro ng bago-ng telepono
glosses_en: like PERS.GEN PN GEN new-LIN phone
comms_internal: You can also say Gusto ni Pedro si/kay Maria. With nonpersonal NPs, ng marks indefiniteness, while ang marks definiteness (Gusto ni Pedro ang bagong telepono). With personal NPs who knows, no apparent difference. Some people classify gusto as a pseudo-verb, like kilala. But all these pseudo-verbs behave differently in respect of the marking available to their participants (kilala 'know a person' allows only ng/ni for X and ang/si for Y, kailangan 'need' allows ng/ni for X and ang/ng for nonpersonal NPs or ang for personal NPs, ayaw 'dislike' allows ng/ni for X and ang/ng/sa for nonpersonal NPs and si/kay for personal NPs). These represent a very small closed class of lexemes which are used with high frequency.
